title: 'We've all grown up with radiators - underfloor heating is a no-brainer'
summary:
Sam Jump, pictured with Wunda's pioneering Rapid Response underfloor heating system, is the grandson of the entrepreneurial founders.
When entrepreneurs Charles and Josephine Pugh rented a property with "uncomfortable and uncontrollable" underfloor heating (UFH), it sparked a move away from the made-to-order furniture world they had been invested in since the late 1970s.
The Pughs’ home heating issue had centred on underfloor screed — a level layer of concrete where piping has traditionally been embedded into — with pipe centres too far apart.
With no controls, there was a slow response time to heat and the floor became too hot.
Wunda Group founders Charles and Josephine Pugh, left, with daughter Josephine and grandson Sam.

title: Will There Be a White Christmas This Year? It Depends on Where You Live
summary:
Are you dreaming of a white Christmas?
For some of us in the U.S., it’s a lock; for others, the odds are sadly slim.
And in many places, they are getting slimmer as global temperatures rise and winter weather gets wetter.
Broadly, the first day of snow is falling later than it used to across the U.S., and the odds of a white Christmas are shrinking.
As for this year, current forecasts aren’t in favor of a snowy Christmas for most of the country.

title: Scientists found climate change hidden in old military air samples
summary:
The research shows that moss spores are now released several weeks earlier than they were in the past, highlighting how quickly natural systems can adjust as the climate warms.
Air sampling in Sweden began in the 1960s as part of efforts to monitor radioactive fallout from nuclear weapons testing.
On average, mosses now begin releasing spores about four weeks earlier than they did in 1990, and the peak of spore dispersal arrives roughly six weeks sooner.
Last year's climate matters more than spring weatherThe findings point to warmer autumns as a key driver of the shift.
Because air samples have been collected from locations across Sweden, researchers can reconstruct ecological shifts over decades and compare trends from north to south.

title: NY climate advocates celebrate rare good news after Gov. Hochul nixes gas hook-up rule
summary:
Climate advocates in New York are celebrating some rare positive news after Gov.
Kathy Hochul signed a law that will likely curb the proliferation of new gas hook-ups statewide.
It meant developers of new homes could pass the cost of gas hook-ups to all utility customers, rather than pay for it themselves.
“This is a massive win for New York’s gas customers, and for clean air and a livable climate.”The victory comes after a tough year for climate priorities in New York.
But according to the Public Utility Law Project the rule was adding $600 million a year to utility costs for all New York homeowners and renters.
